page.title: 01Woodmancote/Nibley area
page.content: Woodmancote/North Nibley is a rural area lying in the shadow of the Cotswold escarpment which shelters the villages from the cold winds. "Nib" comes from "Hnybba" meaning peak. "Ley" is a meadow. Woodmancote is probably the "Woncot" mentioned in Shakespeare's Henry IV. It is a close-knit community and the area is recognised by its monument to Tyndale, a local man. Agriculture is the main form of employment in the area but many people travel elsewhere to work. There is a beautiful medieval church- St.Martins, on the outskirts of Nibley. Woodmancote is a residential area with three old- people's homes and a church- St.Marks. Most people from both areas shop in Dursley or Wotton-under-Edge.
